title: Before 1 January 2020, will a firm or paid backup driver operating a self-driving vehicle face criminal charges in relation to an accident involving a self-driving vehicle in the U.S.?
preds: Its mostly wishful thinking.  Given our windshield bias, hesitation in convicting #carviolence in general, coupled with a fetish for tech, its unlikely that any autonomous car driver will be charged, much less convicted.  Still, the odds are much >0, as there are many eager prosecutors looking for a case to press.
Way late on updating this. Nothing by the end of the year in terms of decisions on the Uber driver case out of Arizona. Would still expect a final decision on whether to file or not in Q1 2020
I'm pretty sure most grand juries aren't handing out a lot of indictments until the New Year.
Guessing at this point that any criminal charges might not come until the new year. No pertinent news reports found lately.
Probably no charges this year at least is the guess...
Moving to no because there's only a couple weeks left.
Adjusting for dwindling question time period. No updates for driver criminal investigation found.

Before 1 January 2020, will a firm or paid backup driver operating a self-driving vehicle face criminal charges in relation to an accident involving a self-driving vehicle in the U.S.? The clock continues to tick not many working days  left in the legal calendar.

Before 1 January 2020, will a firm or paid backup driver operating a self-driving vehicle face criminal charges in relation to an accident involving a self-driving vehicle in the U.S.? The Nov 19 report is out as reported by @jayb. The key issue with a forecast is hitting the time interval which can be difficult in a legal case.

Per quick analysis of today's NTSB hearing report, the human 'safety' driver received significant "blame" for the fatal 2018 Uber crash. Software and other factors were also specifically faulted. Also noting that the report "..by its nature does not contain probable cause".  https://www.forbes.com/sites/bradtempleton/2019/11/19/ntsb-hearing-blames-humans-software-and-policy-for-fatal-uber-robocar-crash/#4624efee4c6d, https://www.ntsb.gov/news/press-releases/Pages/NR20180524.aspx (1st linked) Article excerpt: "The NTSB’s final determination of probable cause put primary blame on the safety driver’s inattention. Contributory causes where Uber’s lack of safety culture, poor monitoring of safety drivers, and lack of countermeasures for automation complacency. They put tertiary blame on the pedestrian’s impaired crossing of the road, and the lack of good regulations at the Arizona and Federal levels. Most notably, they do not attribute the technology failures as causes of the crash..." At this point the main question(s) (..for this question) may be whether the human backup driver might be criminally charged & (if so) by year's end. ..Will continue to look at the NTSB report, and monitor pertinent reaction.
Before 1 January 2020, will a firm or paid backup driver operating a self-driving vehicle face criminal charges in relation to an accident involving a self-driving vehicle in the U.S.?
Slight forecast adjustment based upon newly-seen info. (Pls. see my previous forecast below if interested.)

Prefer not to move toward the overall 'crowd' forecast here until (possibly) after the 11/19/19 probable cause hearing by the NTSB for the 2018 fatal, Uber Arizona crash. IMO: As reported, an NTSB preliminary report (link below) assigns blame to the vehicles' software but (still) may not 'clear' the "safety driver" in that crash.  Update: The second linked article below has the following info. that I've not seen before (re the backup driver): ""A spokeswoman for the Maricopa County attorney’s office, Amanda Steele, said Tempe police “submitted the case with a recommendation of manslaughter . . . and we’re reviewing it for a charging decision.”" 
..One obvious question (for this GJP question) could be whether any criminal charges would be filed by year-end. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-crash/uber-test-vehicles-involved-in-37-crashes-before-fatal-self-driving-incident-idUSKBN1XF2HA https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/trafficandcommuting/pedestrian-in-self-driving-uber-collision-probably-would-have-lived-if-braking-feature-hadnt-been-shut-off-ntsb-finds/2019/11/05/7ec83b9c-ffeb-11e9-9518-1e76abc088b6_story.html

Each day makes this forecast less stressful and the roads safer.

Updating for minor adjustment for time remaining. Finally some word out of Arizona & the NTSB on this matter. Sounds like the NTSB will meet on November 19th to discuss this accident (among I assume other items) & give a final verdict on fault associated (hopefully). So fingers crossed for a final firm update soon after Nov. 19th. "The U.S. National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) will hold a Nov. 19 hearing to determine the probable cause of a March 2018 Uber Technologies Inc (UBER.N) self-driving vehicle crash that killed a pedestrian in Arizona..." 
(Source link: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-crash-safety/ntsb-to-determine-probable-cause-of-fatal-uber-self-driving-crash-idUSKBN1WW2IR) Main questions here seem to be whether any criminal charges will be filed, and - if so - by year-end.
More test will be needed by the ICE carmakers. Companies will not take the full blame.
So far so good, processes and procedures and improved conditions have kept this space clear.
Nothing seems to have changed in this space and that is probably a good thing.
Passage of time update + no new developments currently found re backup driver culpability in Uber 2018 fatal AV incident.

There's a massive prevalence of personal-injury lawyers ready to pounce on this opportunity, partially due to the influx of lawyers from the college graduates during the recession who opted for law school instead of entering the workforce. Now, we have an overabundance of creative and entrepreneurial lawyers.
Passage of time update. No new info. found re 'backup driver' Rafaela Vazquez/Uber ongoing case.

There are a lot of safety procedures built in - although they may (unlikely) fail, this is unlikely to be due to negligence. The chances of the backup driver failing after the self-driving tech fails are low.

I think there will be a very low number of accidents between now and the end date because there are not that many of these cars and many are driven in controlled environments.  although, I don't know if there is any increase in EV trials planned between now and the end date.  I think the bar for criminal charges in the United States is higher than for a civil lawsuit, plus a prosecutor has some discretion not to bring criminal charges.  I think there will be pressure not to bring charges unless the situation is particularly egregious.  Although, if such an egregious accident happens, there would likely be increased pressure to bring criminal charges.   Based on what I know now, the chances seem low.

The absolute number of accidents involving self-driving vehicles is very low.
However given the Uber incident it is possible that drivers are becoming too complacent.
Slight decrease in odds for passing of time. Hoping to hear more out of Tempe in the coming weeks to inform a more accurate forecast.

Extremely low accidents for self-driving cars, evne lower for deaths which would increase probability of criminal case. Timeline also a restriction, as would take time to launch an investigation and to bring charges. BUT if there was such charges would expect both driver and firm to face charges.
Low chance of a major accident, I expect that a small one will be paid out and if it happens, I would say the driver would not be charged
The US wants self driving vehicles to succeed.
These are difficult issues with little precedent.

Adjusting given recent action from Tempe police in relation to the ongoing investigation & potential charging of Rafaela Vasquez in relation to Uber's 2018 accident in Tempe, AZ. This is probably also a good time to zero in on the statement "face criminal charges" rather than "be convicted of a crime". Driverless cars and trucks are coming to the US and cannot be stopped. The legal system in the US will be bent to the will of capital investors, who have anted up between say, $1 and $2 billion already. If anyone is held accountable for a horrible accident, it will fall on a individual, not a firm.

Per a 7/10/19 article link, local police investigation into the 2018 Tempe fatal Uber crash continues, reportedly including actions of the backup driver:   https://www.azcentral.com/story/money/business/tech/2019/07/10/fatal-uber-crash-killed-elaine-herzberg-still-under-investigation/1693956001/

Haven't seen any movement on any potential charges against the driver in the Uber-Tempe accident. Reducing for the time being and seeing if I can find more information on those proceedings. Adjustment: [ 1↓, 10↓, 1↓, 12↑ ]
Law and lawmakers move slowly. Especially against industry in the US. Driver is the most likely as gross negligence is quite common.

This entire question hinges on the Uber Case against the safety driver.  I don't know what the time line is here, but I plan to keep relatively high odds until the Uber safety driver is released from potential charges.

The threshold for facing criminal charges is very high particularly in the case of holding Companies criminally responsible.  More over very few people would actually care to do this, they would much rather just sue in civil court where they can receive a Big check.  Generally, there would also be a requirement for fraud or gross negligence to reach the criminal threshold.    Consider that the only way people face criminal charges for driving a car is they participate in wreckless behaviour.  This is nearly impossible for a self driving car to commit.   See here:  https://www.hg.org/legal-articles/traffic-offenses-which-can-lead-to-criminal-charges-48321
Still little/no news surrounding the charging of the Uber driver from the Tempe, AZ accident. Regressing to a less aggressive position for the time being Adjustment: [ ↔, 5↓, ↔, 5↑ ]

The chances that a firm would be prosecuted  for a failure of their self driving cars is almost nonexistent. Unless a massive conspiracy to ignore/falsify performance reports is uncovered, there just isn't an avenue to prosecute. Since there are already discussions about prosecuting the backup driver from a previous fatal crash, I think this will be the most likely way any prosecutions related to self-driving cars would unfold.
We aren’t quite there yet. I think sometime in 2020 or beginning of 2021 a case will happen but the field is still developing and isn’t quite to that level yet.

To my knowledge at present the only self driving cars are operators by their developers under trials, now permitted by law. To file charges prosecutor would not just have to show that a bug/mistake by the developers caused the accident, but that there was negligence that led to this. In a field that is new and developing, they would have to show that the company knew there were specific risks, but ignored them, or didn't take sufficient steps to address them. Its more likely that a backup driver might lose concentration and fail to step in when a self driving car is making a mistake, and could be held liable for that. Since neither a firm or a driver has yet had charges filed, the chances are relatively low of either occurring in the next 6-7 months.

The backup driver in the fatal 2018 Arizona self-driving crash reportedly may still face charges. Cannot find published info. to the contrary, at present.. https://www.theverge.com/2019/3/5/18252423/uber-wont-be-charged-with-fatal-self-driving-crash-says-prosecutor https://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/news/autonomous-vehicles-to-take-us-mail-between-phoenix-and-dallas-11298677 https://www.irishtimes.com/business/innovation/who-s-to-blame-when-a-self-driving-car-crashes-1.3902166

my assumptions are that aut. cars are more of  marketing then actual. aut. cars are rare and hardly driving, hence the chance that there will an accident is low. the main reason for a lawsuit is again a publicity stunt. if there will be such a move, no benefit will come from suing the driver, only the firm.

all the self driving tests are covered by agreements with the local governments at the moment. so the timeframe for the question is too short.  However where lawsuits are concerned logic does not preclude an attempt.
Seems already if the surge towards total autonomy of these has cooled for the moment. No one, and or company wants the responsibility of a bus load of dead nuns.
People give a consent to the rules of the car usage and it is clearly written and communicated that the cars do not self-drive themselves, they just assist you.
The number of such events that make it to court in the time period doesn't seem to match the number of reportable accidents where a need to sue is present.

Yes, and accident will happen and there will be criminal charges. However, the backup driver will have far less legal resources at his/her disposal compared to the firm (Google/Uber) and will be held liable.

I base my forecast on the probability that there will be more glitches in self driving vehicles and therefore there will more chances for someone to face criminal charges. I put 60% on a firm solely because firms usually have a higher probability to be sued.
Unclear what criminal charges could be brought against a firm. Backup driver could assume negligence, but small number and general low speed of testing reduces changes of criminal event occurring.
Adjusting forecast a bit closer to current consensus
The backup driver is the only human in the loop.

At present, Autonomous vehicles drive an average of 2,000,000 miles yearly and can drive 4,200 miles before drivers must re-engage due to some process error. For comparison, 3 trillion miles are driven yearly in the U.S. and collision fatalities in the United States occur only once per 100 million miles driven. Assuming that autonomous vehicles are at least as safe as non-autonomous ones, this suggests that traffic fatalities are unlikely to occur sufficiently frequently to warrant serious criminal actions against a firm. 
	However, human error is a difficult one to predict with any new technology. Even in the case linked in the question, the backup driver was referred for charges. This does increase the likelihood of criminal charges faced by a backup driver. 
(https://www.axios.com/how-often-self-driving-cars-disengage-cfa9ed53-c562-40a0-9f2d-3ae2ac7d9a4a.html)

While self-driving cars are making headlines, it is unlikely that a firm (and even more so an individual paid backup driver) will be criminally charged in relation to an accident involving a self-driving incident. One is because the laws and regulations surrounding this tech is largely undeveloped. Second, in cases where this has occurred, it is usually not the fault of the vehicle (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/05/technology/uber-self-driving-car-arizona.html). In the above example for example, its quoted "Yavapai County Attorney’s Office, which reviewed the case, said in a letter dated Monday that there was “no basis for criminal liability for the Uber corporation.” It is unlikely that even a human-operated car would have successfully avoided the women crossing an unmarked road (no crosswalk) the road in pitch black.

As we have seen in the rare cases that we have on file of self-driving vehicles being involved in crashes, the back-up driver is usually the party held responsible. In Arizona, Uber was not held responsible for the death of a pedestrian and the back-up driver was investigated further by police (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-crash-autonomous/uber-not-criminally-liable-in-fatal-2018-arizona-self-driving-crash-prosecutors-idUSKCN1QM2O8). In the next seven months, I highly doubt there will be a significant amount of self-driving vehicles on the roads to actually crash with people, therefore giving this a 60% chance of not happening.

Autonomous cars and self driving vehicles are not prevalent enough on the road right now for there to be an accident given the allotted time. The most relevant situation to examine in order to understand the possible precedent or proceedings is a case with Uber, in which neither Uber nor the firm were liable in the crash. 
As a firm (Uber) has initially been cleared of criminal liability (to date), registering the highest possibility that criminal charges of some type could be filed against a backup driver if this event occurs in the coming months. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-crash-autonomous/uber-not-criminally-liable-in-fatal-2018-arizona-self-driving-crash-prosecutors-idUSKCN1QM2O8
[2] https://www.lawyernc.com/blog/2018/04/self-driving-car-accident-responsibility/
[3] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/05/technology/uber-self-driving-car-arizona.html; https://www.nhtsa.gov/technology-innovation/automated-vehicles-safety

Extremizing slightly after some further digging into potential ongoing investigation into the safety-driver from Uber's accident last year. Various reports suggest an investigation into charges up-to & including vehicular manslaughter may be ongoing (potentially beginning as early as late last year). Tempe Police's department site quotes an investigation time table of "... up to 6 months..." so the timetable should be well before Jan. 1st, 2020 to reach a conclusion. Increasing odds of investigation completing before time to 100% & odds of conviction/plea-deal up to 65:35 (2↓ on Yes, paid-driver to distribute non-zero on other options)

It being developed carefully adhering to many safety features. There is least chance to have any accident and even if that happens, it is unlikely that will lead to face criminal charges. If that happens then again a firm will more likely to affect than a driver.

I predict, there'll be no firm or paid backup driver that'll be facing criminal charges in the U.S. 
It never happened before and If there'll be an accident there'll be a civil case.

Airplanes crash all the time without facing criminal charges. EVEN, when the policy is not to fix the problem when it is cheaper to pay off the victims.
I don't see how there can be any charges filed UNLESS there is intent to endanger people's lives due to gross negligence, at the very least. Not unlikely, given the cavalier attitude of those responsible for the 2008 credit default swap scandal (also notice almost nobody got charged in the US although Greece came down hard on their own citizens.)
However, given the intense media scrutiny of the technology, the risk of things going wrong because somebody rushed the technology out in favor of profits is very much lessened. Although, that doesn't mean that the technology will be safe. Look at how Samsung's foldable phone fiasco unfolded.

Based on a sample size of one (the Uber crash) this seems unlikely. However, it also seems that the back-up driver in that incident is in more serious trouble than the company and could still be charged so I am giving that option a few more points.
Unlikely for a lawsuit to be filed, but if it does it will be against the manufacturer

Slightly adjusting forecast upon a bit of additional research. Whether any 'self-driving' vehicle (.. autonomous with a backup driver, i.e.; Level 3, I assume..) accident with injury/death meets recognized criteria where criminal charges would generally be warranted under 'usual' (or traditional) circumstances, is pertinent to this question, IMO. 
https://dictionary.law.com/Default.aspx?selected=2212 ..Different states and different manufacturers also have differing approaches re self-driving vehicle liability.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car_liability https://www.lawyernc.com/blog/2018/04/self-driving-car-accident-responsibility/ https://www.shouselaw.com/personal-injury/driverless-car-accidents.html

I don't think there is much of an outside view to draw from here since such an event has never happened before.  The inside view suggests looking at the ongoing investigation into the fatal Uber crash and to estimate possible other incidents. Uber crash:
- As others here have noted, the county attorney decided not to file criminal charges against Uber.
- As others here have also noted, the backup driver may still face criminal charges. I'm not sure how to evaluate whether that will happen. Apparently, she could be charged for "vehicular manslaughter, according to a police report in June". [1] The law dictionary defines that as "the crime of causing the death of a human being due to illegal driving of an automobile, including gross negligence, drunk driving, reckless driving or speeding". [2] Examining gross negligence a bit more: "Gross negligence is the extreme indifference to or reckless disregard for the safety of others. Gross negligence is more than simple carelessness or failure to act. It is willful behavior done with extreme disregard for the health and safety of others. [...] While most car accidents involve ordinary negligence such as careless driving, an injury accident caused by a drunk driver may in some cases be considered an act of gross negligence, depending on the circumstances." [3] The evidence seems to point to gross negligence for me, but I should note that the backup driver claims to have paid attention. [4] Filing charges also does not require proving gross negligence, but just asserting gross negligence. Unfortunately, I'm not a law professional and find this hard to judge for that reason. I also don't know that much about the incentives of the relevant stakeholders here. It's noteworthy that the accident happened almost a year ago and she still has not been charged. I'd estimate the probability that she will be charged before the end of the year at 65%. Other crashes:
- In another context, I estimated 70% for at least one fatal accident before the end of the ear. I'm not sure if nonfatal crashes could result in criminal charges though.
- In the Uber case, it took the prosecutors 8 to 9 months to come to a decision whether to prosecute.
- Charging the firm seems less likely than charging the driver given the Uber incident. Both seem very unlikely given the timeline of the Uber case. I'd estimate 10% of charging the firm conditional on another accident and 20% of charging the driver conditional on another accident. This gives 7% for the firm and 14% for the backup driver. Putting that all together, we get 70% for a backup driver, 7% for a firm. This gives 65% for a driver alone, 2% for a firm alone, 5% for both, and 28% for neither. This is most likely to change if somebody with more legal background has a convincing take on the Uber case. [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-uber-crash-autonomous/uber-not-criminally-liable-in-fatal-2018-arizona-self-driving-crash-prosecutors-idUSKCN1QM2O8
[2] https://dictionary.law.com/Default.aspx?selected=2212
[3] https://www.sawayalaw.com/blog/ordinary-negligence-vs-gross-negligence/
[4] https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/dr-gridlock/wp/2018/06/22/uber-safety-drivers-phone-was-streaming-the-voice-ahead-of-deadly-driverless-crash-police-find/?utm_term=.e25faa92723e

They can’t get pulled over, eventually the police will have to rely on professionalism and actually have to do detective work on crimes like it’s the 1940s.  In a fit of rage I’m sure they’ll take it out on former criminals and stalk them, particularly as their sources of illicit funds for not working become exhausted.

In part from a quick review of articles covering the Arizona fatal Uber 'self-driving' crash of 2018, it currently appears that: -- The Arizona case has 'collided with' murky and unsettled legal/regulatory realms. (https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2018/03/can-you-sue-a-robocar/556007/) -- Though the company has initially been cleared in one local ruling, the human driver/attendant in the Uber crash could still face charges in some form. (https://www.theverge.com/2019/3/5/18252423/uber-wont-be-charged-with-fatal-self-driving-crash-says-prosecutor) -- Autonomous driving companies in general appear to have become more cautious with testing activities since the fatal crash. (https://www.thedrive.com/tech/27023/10-lessons-from-ubers-fatal-self-driving-car-crash) -- Self-driving cars and ride-sharing vehicles are 'on the road' in increasing numbers. (https://www.pcmag.com/article/366797/which-self-driving-cars-put-in-the-most-fully-autonomous-mil) Drawing from my current forecast for a partly-related GJP question, (https://www.gjopen.com/questions/1129-between-8-march-and-31-december-2019-how-many-accidents-involving-a-self-driving-vehicle-operating-in-autonomous-mode-in-the-u-s-will-result-in-a-fatality), suggest that a relatively low number of *new*, *fatal* self-driving crashes -- most likely zero to two -- may occur during the question's time period. 
Guessing that injuries (allegedly) caused by a self-driving vehicle may also be relatively low in number -- and may also encounter a similarly murky, arduous legal environment. (Some of this may depend upon the state in which a person was injured (or worse). https://www.nolo.com/legal-encyclopedia/if-youre-hit-by-a-self-driving-car.html) Mainly reflecting an unclear and still-developing legal situation plus an anticipated low number of new (fatal) accidents, currently conjecturing the highest initial probability for the 'no' option of this question. 
As a firm (Uber) has initially been cleared of criminal liability (to date), registering the next highest possibility that criminal charges of some type could be filed against a backup driver, particularly in the Arizona fatality.
Not enough vehicles on road yet. Maybe by 2025.

Using the Uber Tempe, AZ accident as precedent here. Despite what I would classify as, at best, risky conduct of Uber as it pertains to the state of operation of their vehicles at the time (i.e. Automatic Emergency Braking disabled due to excess false positives) prosecutors deemed them not criminally liable. Such a verdict has not yet been reached for the operator of the vehicle (Who it's worth noting was apparently watching Hulu at the time of the accident). A final verdict in this case will set precedent moving forward, I suspect there should be a verdict one way or another prior to Jan. 1st, 2020 (90%) with 60:40 odds for the driver being found criminally liable. This gives a 54% chance of the backup driver being held liable. As far as any other cases, this would require another case with possible criminal liability to arise in the near future, and even then it would likely not close by the time the deadline has passed. Classifying this as near-impossible.
If a corporation is a person then the corporation will be changed unless the backup driver is operating the motor vehical
The technology improves, the deployments are primarily in ideal climate, the numbers are still small thru 2019.

I believe that many tech firms are used to operating with concerns about failure at much lower levels than almost  all manufacturers.  The Blue Screen of Death" is an incovenience. Tesla and Uber crashes are deadly serious. Self-driving cars are not ready for prime time and someone will be held responsible.

I don't really think there are enough self-driving vehicles on the road right now for there to be an accident before the alloted time. The only crash I could find on a precursory search was one involving Uber, and though they had disabled one of the safety features to prevent erratic behavior from the car, neither Uber nor the mfgr were liable in the crash. This would set a precendent for case law in Arizona. If another crash happens in Arizona I would assume the victim would need to take the case higher than state level. 
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/05/technology/uber-self-driving-car-arizona.html; https://www.nhtsa.gov/technology-innovation/automated-vehicles-safety

The laws are too vague at this point to hold someone accountable and there are not enough self-driving vehicles on the road.  It will be difficult to know whom to charge and that will make it hard to charge someone.
I don't think the US legal system has figured out rules to try such a prosecution yet.  The likely hood of an incident occurring is relatively low as well.
the availability of self-driving cars and their numbers are too less to have a case by January 2020.
